message.content: This question requires some basic knowledge about freezing temperatures and preserving food. In order to keep the ice frozen and the salad bar cold, the person might pour sodium over the ice. Sodium has a freezing point of 98 degrees Celsius (208 degrees Fahrenheit), so it can help lower the temperature and prevent the ice from melting. Option (B) is incorrect because putting the ice in the sun would cause it to melt. Option (C) is incorrect because melting the ice on a stove would also cause it to become liquid. Option (D) is incorrect because throwing the ice away would defeat the purpose of keeping the salad bar cold.

This question requires some basic knowledge of the properties of sodium and the freezing point of water. Sodium is commonly used as a source of heat in chemical reactions because it reacts violently with water, producing heat. By pouring sodium over the ice, the heat produced from the reaction will keep the ice from melting and thus keep the salad bar cold. Option (B) is incorrect because putting the ice in the sun would cause it to melt. Option (C) is incorrect because melting the ice on a stove would completely remove the ice. Option (D) is incorrect because throwing the ice away would also not keep the salad bar cold.

This is because sodium reacts exothermically with water, meaning it releases heat when it comes into contact with moisture. By pouring sodium over the ice, it will lower the temperature of the ice and help keep it frozen.
